title.default: What best describes your relation to data?

text.default: I gather or create data through program or service delivery.
I interpret trends and patterns in datasets, and communicate conclusions and recommendations to others.
I use advanced analytics (e.g., inferential statistics, algorithms, data mining) to develop solutions to business problems.
I make operational and strategic planning decisions based on data-derived insights.
I manage government data throughout its entire lifecycle.
I design, implement and maintain the architecture for datasets, databases and data warehouses.

title.default: About You
What best describes your knowledge of how data is used your organization?

text.default: I am unsure how my organization or area collects, manages, or uses data.
I understand the workflow to collect, manage, analyze and apply data to solve business problems.
I understand the data management processes in my organization, from creation and initial storage to archiving and deletion.
I develop data management policies in my organization to promote the preservation, protection, access, re-use and shareability of government data assets.

title.default: Data Culture
What best describes your familiarity with data ethics and security?

text.default: I am unsure about guidelines on the responsible use and sharing of data.
I understand key elements about responsible use and sharing of data, like completing a PIAs.
I regularly identify ethics or security risks around data collection or usage, and establish controls to ensure data confidentiality, integrity, and security.
I have developed or overseen compliance with privacy protection policies and procedures.

title.default: Data Ethics and Security
What best describes your ability to formulate research questions?

text.default: I am beginning to learn about the kinds of problems can be solved by using data.
I am able to formulate questions that can be answered with simple data queries.
I develop projects based on questions that need complex data queries and multiple iterations to resolve.
I regularly translate business needs into analytic or reporting requirements, including progress monitoring and performance evaluation.

title.default: Asking the Right Questions
What best describes the data sources / strategies you use to find data?

text.default: I use search engines like Google to search for data.
I know a few data portals and public databases, and can choose the most relevant ones to help me with my work.
I use advanced methods and software to collect and combine data from multiple sources to solve business problems.
I know when the available data cannot solve a given problem, and can generate or obtain new data if needed.

title.default: Finding Data
What best describes the strategies you use to clean data?

text.default: I did not know that data might need to be checked, cleaned or normalized. I use data as is.
I can identify common data quality issues (e.g. empty fields, duplicates) and manually fix invalid records and errors.
I always make sure that my data is clean, easy-to-access, and machine readable.
I can use automated scripts to detect duplication, fix invalid records, or address empty fields.

title.default: Cleaning Data
What best describes the strategies you use to manage data?

text.default: I am beginning to learn about managing data sets.

I can collect, edit and store simple datasets in a spreadsheet, and or am familiar with the importance of documenting datasets using appropriate metadata descriptors like author, date created, access rights.
I can design, implement or manage large databases (e.g., big data, real-time dashboards) and I follow data management standards.
I can integrate collected data into information systems, set up data pipelines or improve the interoperability of data, and I can help creation or maintain data dictionaries.

title.default: Managing Data
What best describes how you analyze data?

text.default: I use basic summaries of data to read information.
I am familiar with common descriptive statistics to identify basic relationships, trends and patterns in data.
I can use advanced and inferential statistics to identify significant relationships, such as linear regressions and decision trees.
I can use predictive or machine learning techniques, such as clustering, forecasting, and natural language processing.

title.default: Analyze Data
What best describes how you visualize data?

text.default: I am beginning to learn about data visualization techniques. I usually choose standard visualizations based on what looks best.
I can represent basic information in a table or graph (e.g., pie charts, bar graphs).
I design interactive charts or dashboards using static data, and choose visualizations from a range of options (e.g., treemaps, ribbons).
I design sophisticated visualizations that update automatically with real-time data.

title.default: Visualize Data
What best describes how you communicate data outputs?

text.default: I am beginning to learn about how to communicate data findings, or how the data fits into a broader context.
I can develop basic reports or prepare simple visual summaries that illustrate and support the main data insights.
I can create complex reports that identify key takeaway points and make recommendations.
I can use data and visualizations to build a compelling narrative that is tailored to the audience

title.default: Communicating with Data
What best describes your ability to critically assess and interpret data insights?

text.default: I take reports and visualizations at face value without questioning their accuracy and message.
I am aware that data needs to be critically assessed, but am not comfortable doing so myself.
I can critically assess the accuracy, assumptions, reliability and validity of data when presented as evidence (e.g., correlation is not causation).
I have the knowledge needed to meaningfully interpret and translate data insights into action, new ideas, or innovative solutions.

title.default: Assessing & Interpreting Data Outputs
